title.rendered: New Logo and Packaging for Kashi by Jones Knowles Ritchie

content.rendered:
Established in 1984, Kashi produces natural and plant-based foods including cereals, powders, entrees, and snacks. Launched by a husband and wife team, Kashi was purchased by Kellogg’s in 2000 but runs as an independent business posting $500 million in sales in 2014, making it one of the biggest natural and Non-GMO Project Verified foods business in the U.S.. Earlier this month, Kashi introduced a new logo and packaging designed by Jones Knowles Ritchie.

With the inspiration that “good clean food deserves good clean design,” Kashi® is launching a new and refreshed brand identity that reflects its belief that food should not only taste good, but do good. Created in partnership with Jones Knowles Ritchie, the new look is a commitment to visually telling the brand story of bringing people close to the food they love. Initial changes will be reflected across the company’s logo and packaging portfolio.

Kashi press release

Similar to yesterday’s Paco Rabbane post, the logo remains mostly the same but has been improved for readability, crispness, and functionality. As a logo (old or new) it isn’t the most interesting or innovative, just a serif with an ambiguous grain going across it and ending as the tittle of the “i” — a detail that JKR has taken advantage of below to introduce a “hi” graphic that doesn’t seem to appear anywhere else at the moment but is cute nonetheless. The revised grain is smoother and the revised serif is sharper. Hard to argue against it and it helps shed some of the Kumbaya aesthetic of the wobbly grain. Taking the logo out of the horrible holding shape with its weird border is, on its own, reason to celebrate.

As a healthy food pioneer for over 30 years, Kashi has always been committed to creating foods that enable uplifting health. With an entire portfolio of Non-GMO Project Verified products and ever-increasing organic offerings, Kashi sought to develop packaging to better reflect its progressive food values, highlight the stories behind the foods and also revisit some of the inspiration from its original packaging. Kashi was one of the first brands to use white cereal boxes and, with this packaging refresh, is again shaking up the natural and organic category with a bold departure from imagery reliant on farm and field visuals. The new design features food front and center against a clean white canvas and accented with a design that is unmistakably contemporary – with clean lines, vivid colors and straightforward typography.

Kashi press release

As you’ll see in the packaging below, one of the things that makes it work so well is the literally straightforward food photography. It makes a good case for WYSIWYG, looking natural and simple.

Kashi is also one of the first brands to incorporate editorial-style stories on all packaging about how the food was made and where it comes from – including employees, farmers and friends of Kashi who had a deep impact on it.

Kashi press release

The old packaging was semi okay but there was nothing distinctive about it — even its claim as being one of the first cereal boxes to be white now isn’t that special as a lot of food products have gone white. The sampling of old packaging I cobbled together may not be the most chronologically accurate and there is probably old and new stuff mixed in but there is little consistency and a free-for-all of make-it-look-organic-! graphic devices. The new packaging is amazingly simple and restrained, with a big, detailed photo of the product, a big logo, and information neatly organized into tiny compartments. The “Organic Indigo Morning” box is so good. They have managed to take the white-space-big-product-photo trend and make it feel fresh and contemporary or at least more refined. The supporting use of Lineto’s Circular doesn’t feel quite right and not just because it’s yet another use of Circular but it’s operating on a different graphic wavelength as the logo and product image. Maybe even a lighter weight of it would have worked better.

Overall, the packaging and ads are an interesting blend of retail and editorial design that make the products look like very tasty annual reports. The change would have benefited from a newer-er logo but I can understand that they would want to keep that equity. Now, about that Dark Cocoa Karma cereal, let’s put some of that in my belly.
